class="mck-u-links-inline">To future-proof citizens’ ability to work, they will require new skills—but which ones? A survey of 18,000 people in 15 countries suggests those that governments may wish to prioritize.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fpublic%20and%20social%20sector%2Four%20insights%2Fdefining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work%2Fdefining-the-skills-citizens-will-need-in-the-future-of-work-final.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="defining-the-skills-citizens-will-need-in-the-future-of-work-final" data-layer-report-name="defining-the-skills-citizens-will-need-in-the-future-of-work-final>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (19 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>We know that</strong> digital and AI technologies are transforming the world of work and that today’s workforce will need to learn new skills and learn to continually adapt as new occupations emerge. We also know that the <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever">COVID-19 crisis has accelerated this transformation</a>. We are less clear, however, about the specific skills tomorrow’s workers will require.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Research by the McKinsey Global Institute has looked at the kind of jobs that will be lost, as well as those that will be created, as automation, AI, and robotics take hold. And it has inferred the type of high-level skills that will become increasingly important as a result.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1c1a8ef7-a7c3-4d93-a2bb-a5090993b1c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1c1a8ef7-a7c3-4d93-a2bb-a5090993b1c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more information, see “<em><a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/skill-shift-automation-and-the-future-of-the-workforce">Skill shift: Automation and the future of the workforce</a></em>,” May 23, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The need for manual and physical skills, as well as basic cognitive ones, will decline, but demand for technological, social and emotional, and higher cognitive skills will grow.</p>
<p>Governments are keen to help their citizens develop in these areas, but it is hard to devise curricula and the best learning strategies without being more precise about the skills needed. It is difficult to teach what is not well defined.</p>
<p>We, therefore, conducted research that we hope will help definitions take shape and could contribute to future-proof citizens’ skills for the world of work.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cbb2385b-f717-4a74-a60d-98fdce991f42"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cbb2385b-f717-4a74-a60d-98fdce991f42" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For previous McKinsey work on the role of governments in adapting to the future of work, see Marco Dondi, Solveigh Hieronimus, Julia Klier, Peter Puskas, Dirk Schmautzer, and Jörg Schubert, “<em><a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/a-government-blueprint-to-adapt-the-ecosystem-to-the-future-of-work">A government blueprint to adapt the ecosystem to the future of work</a>,”</em> February 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> The research identified a set of 56 foundational skills that will benefit all citizens and showed that higher proficiency in them is already associated with a higher likelihood of employment, higher incomes, and job satisfaction.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="849edd36-06ad-4116-9e11-c304df67ea56"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="849edd36-06ad-4116-9e11-c304df67ea56" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The research was conducted in 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Defining foundational skills for citizens</h2>
<p>Some work will, of course, be specialized. But in a labor market that is more automated, digital, and dynamic, all citizens will benefit from having a set of foundational skills that help them fulfill the following three criteria, no matter the sector in which they work or their occupation:</p>
<ul>
    <li>add value beyond what can be done by automated systems and intelligent machines</li>
    <li>operate in a digital environment</li>
    <li>continually adapt to new ways of working and new occupations</li>
</ul>
<p>We used academic research and McKinsey’s experience in adult training to define what these foundational skills might be (Exhibit 1). We started from four broad skill categories—cognitive, digital, interpersonal, and self-leadership—then identified 13 separate skill groups belonging to those categories.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d2f8013d-de08-4391-80ac-1722f6bf67c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d2f8013d-de08-4391-80ac-1722f6bf67c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">To drive toward a more detailed definition of future skills required, we found it useful to divide the social and emotional category used by the McKinsey Global Institute into two separate ones: interpersonal and self-leadership.</span></span></span></a></span> Communication and mental flexibility are two skill groups that belong to the cognitive category, for example, while teamwork effectiveness belongs to the interpersonal category.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Our research identified 56 foundational skills that will help citizens thrive in the future of work." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Looking for still more precision, we identified 56 distinct elements of talent (DELTAs) that fall within these skills groups. We call them DELTAs, rather than skills, because they are a mix of skills and attitudes. “Adaptability” and “coping with uncertainty” are attitudes, for example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5897478b-8ed2-4e85-9a41-09a1251c75c2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5897478b-8ed2-4e85-9a41-09a1251c75c2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A still finer segmentation of each skill group into more DELTAs would be possible. We limited ourselves, however, to DELTAs that require a distinct approach to their development and assessment.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>DELTA proficiency and outcomes</h2>
<p>From here, we conducted two further pieces of research. First, we sought to gauge the level of proficiency in the 56 DELTAs among today’s workers compared with the level we believe will be required to future-proof citizens’ ability to work. Second, we sought to gauge whether proficiency in these DELTAs was already associated with certain work-related outcomes.</p>
<h3>Proficiency</h3>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: Evaluating proficiency levels for DELTAs</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>To assess respondents’ proficiency levels</strong> for each DELTA, we gave them three different sentences that described certain behaviors, choices, and preferences in different situations. Respondents were asked to choose the sentence that best described themselves, even though none or more than one might be relevant. Each sentence was associated with a different level of proficiency.</p>
<p>For example, here are the options we provided to gauge efficiency in the “structured problem solving” DELTA (within the critical thinking skill group):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Option 1: I can solve day-to-day problems easily, but I often need assistance with complex problems </li>
    <li>Option 2: I can break larger problems into parts and find solutions for them</li>
    <li>Option 3: I routinely break complex problems down into parts, identify their causes, and find solutions</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>To ascertain proficiency levels, we defined a desirable level of proficiency in each of the 56 DELTAs, then devised a psychometric questionnaire to assess respondents’ proficiency against this bar. Eighteen thousand people from 15 countries completed the online questionnaire and were given a score on a scale of 0 to 100 for each DELTA (see the sidebar “Example: Evaluating proficiency levels for DELTAs”).</p>
<p>The results showed respondents’ proficiency was lowest in two skill groups in the digital category—software use and development and understanding digital systems. Proficiency in the skill groups for communication and planning and ways of working—both in the cognitive category—was also lower than average (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Respondents’ proficiency was lowest in two skill groups in the digital category—‘software use and development’ and ‘understanding digital systems.’" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Overall, survey participants with a  university degree had higher average proficiency scores across 56 distinct  elements of talent, suggesting that those with higher levels of education are better prepared for changes in the workplace.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>We also examined whether proficiency was linked to education. Overall, survey participants with a university degree had higher average DELTA proficiency scores than those without, suggesting—perhaps not surprisingly—that participants with higher levels of education are better prepared for changes in the workplace. However, a higher level of education is not associated with higher proficiency in all DELTAs. The association holds true for many DELTAs in the cognitive and digital categories. But for many within the self-leadership and interpersonal categories, such as “self-confidence,” “coping with uncertainty,” “courage and risk-taking,” “empathy,” “coaching,” and “resolving conflicts,” there is no such association.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aefcf8bf-0295-4c79-a735-5b832bdbc2f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aefcf8bf-0295-4c79-a735-5b832bdbc2f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Predictive models based on three different statistical techniques failed to find a correlation.</span></span></span></a></span> For some DELTAs, more education was associated with lower proficiency, “humility” being an example.</p>
<p>Exhibit 3 lists the DELTAs where proficiency has the highest and lowest correlation with the level of education. (Some have a negative coefficient.)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Proficiency in certain DELTAs is not necessarily linked to education." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. <h3>Outcomes</h3>
<p>We went on to test whether proficiency in the DELTAs was already helping people in the world of work; the results showed that survey respondents with higher DELTA proficiencies were, on average, more likely to be those that were employed, with higher incomes, and higher job satisfaction. Different DELTAs were more strongly associated with these three work-related outcomes, however.</p>
<p>Holding all variables constant—including demographic variables and proficiency in all other elements—we found employment was most strongly associated with proficiency in several DELTAs within the self-leadership category, namely “adaptability,” “coping with uncertainty,” “synthesizing messages,” and “achievement orientation” (Exhibit 4, part 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ba5c94a-75d5-42fc-878a-541f7ff6a42c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ba5c94a-75d5-42fc-878a-541f7ff6a42c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution—holding all other variables constant—to the probability of a survey participant being employed among those whose income was below the median or those with no income. People with income above the median were excluded to avoid skewed results because of their higher proficiency in DELTAs. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>High incomes were most strongly associated with proficiency in the four skill groups where overall proficiency levels were lowest among respondents—namely understanding digital systems, software use and development, planning and ways of working, and communication (the first two fall within the digital category and the latter two within the cognitive category).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="40d4c006-c909-445e-83ea-9bc77f56a191"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="40d4c006-c909-445e-83ea-9bc77f56a191" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These skill groups show the largest difference in proficiency between survey participants with income below the median income in their country and those in the top quintile.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Digital proficiency seems to be particularly associated with higher incomes: a respondent with higher digital proficiency across all digital DELTAs was 41 percent more likely to earn a top-quintile income than respondents with lower digital proficiency.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e42ea3c-9ef9-4b94-baaf-0cba16fff8ad"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e42ea3c-9ef9-4b94-baaf-0cba16fff8ad" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Our assessment model had three levels of proficiency (3 being the highest level) for each of the 56 DELTAs. Here, respondents with higher digital proficiency are those judged to be at level 3. Those with lower digital proficiency are those at level 2. All else being constant, a respondent at level 3 is 41% more likely to be earning a top-quintile income than a respondent at level 2.  </span></span></span></a></span> The equivalent comparison was 30 percent for cognitive DELTAs, 24 percent for self-leadership DELTAs, and 14 percent for interpersonal DELTAs.</p>
<p>That said, the four DELTAs most strongly associated with high incomes were  “work-plan development” and “asking the right questions,” both in the cognitive category; “self-confidence,” a self-leadership DELTA; and “organizational awareness,” an interpersonal DELTA (Exhibit 4, part 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="67037731-cd1d-49c3-9963-cb9924d084f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="67037731-cd1d-49c3-9963-cb9924d084f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution—holding all other variables constant—to the probability of a survey participant being in the top quintile for income.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<!-- -->
<p>Job satisfaction is also associated with certain DELTAs, especially those in the self-leadership category. Holding all variables, including income, constant, “self-motivation and wellness,” “coping with uncertainty,” and “self-confidence,” had the highest impact on respondents’ job satisfaction (Exhibit 4, part 3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36fd74ca-e60d-4e06-a5b0-0a4a4f6977e4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36fd74ca-e60d-4e06-a5b0-0a4a4f6977e4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution—holding all other variables constant—to the probability of a survey participant being either “fulfilled and satisfied” or “satisfied” with their job, as opposed to “somewhat satisfied” or “dissatisfied.”</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Notably, proficiency in two self-leadership DELTAs—“self-confidence” and “coping with uncertainty”—ranked among the top three most predictive DELTAs for two out of the three outcomes (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="We ranked the top three DELTAs in which proficiency predicts better outcomes for employment, high income, and job satisfaction." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/defining%20the%20skills%20citizens%20will%20need%20in%20the%20future%20world%20of%20work/svgz-deltasfutureskillsneeded_ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>How DELTAs could help shape education and adult training</h2>
<p>Our findings help define the particular skills citizens are likely to require in the future world of work and suggest how proficiency in them can influence work-related outcomes, namely employment, income, and job satisfaction. This, in turn, suggests three actions governments may wish to take.</p>
<h3>Reform education systems</h3>
<p>Our research suggests governments could consider reviewing and updating curricula to focus more strongly on the DELTAs. Given the weak correlation between proficiency in self-leadership and interpersonal DELTAs and higher levels of education, a strong curricula focus on these soft skills may be appropriate.</p>
<p>Governments could also consider leading further research. Many governments and academics have started to define the taxonomies of the skills citizens will require, but few have done so at the level described here. Moreover, few, if any, have undertaken the considerable amount of research required to identify how best to develop and assess such skills. For instance, for each DELTA within the curriculum, research would be required to define progression and proficiency levels achievable at different ages and to design and test developmental strategies and assessment models. The solutions for different DELTAs are likely to differ widely. For example, the solutions to develop and assess “self-awareness and self-management” would differ from those required for “work-plan development or “data analysis.”</p>
<p>In addition, governments could consider setting up institutions for research and innovation in education to fund the research, facilitate researchers’ access to schools to test innovative solutions, and establish which methods work for which DELTAs. They could also make the emerging data and insights available to researchers and educators in the private sector.</p>
<h3>Reform adult-training systems</h3>
<p>The majority of respondents we surveyed—like the majority of people in society at large—were no longer in national education systems. Raising proficiency in the DELTAs would therefore require continuous adult training. The fact that proficiency in digital DELTAs—shown to improve the chances of achieving higher incomes—was lower among older survey respondents who had left the national educational system illustrates this point.</p>
<p>The curricula of adult-training courses may also have to change. For example, our research has shown that self-leadership DELTAs may be particularly important for employment outcomes, yet these are not commonly covered by adult-training programs. For example, in an online scan of adult-training programs, we found that courses or modules to develop DELTAs within the skill groups of goal achievement or self-awareness and self-management were 20 times less common than those to develop communication DELTAs. That could be an urgent gap to fill to adequately respond to the wave of unemployment caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.</p>
<p>Specific actions that might encourage relevant adult learning include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Establish an AI aggregator of training programs to attract adult learners and encourage lifelong learning. </em>AI algorithms could guide users on whether they need to upskill or reskill for a new profession and shortlist relevant training programs. To develop accurate algorithms, governments would need to collect and organize data on market demand for jobs and skills, as well as data on training programs. Programs listed should include those that teach DELTAs correlated to work-related outcomes. Self-leadership DELTAs could be particularly important given their link to employment.</li>
    <li><em>Introduce a skill-based certification system.</em> Occupation-based qualifications risk becoming outdated rapidly as occupations requiring new skills emerge. Hence, skills-based accreditation may better suit employers’ needs. Providers could develop programs that cover the practical skills and DELTAs required to perform a certain occupation, but add new components or remove old ones as those occupations evolved. Several AI start-ups have developed algorithms capable of identifying and updating the skill sets required for different occupations. Governments could adapt these to enable a dynamic, skill-based certification system.</li>
    <li><em>Fund schemes that encourage a higher focus on DELTAs.</em> Some governments award lifelong learning grants to their citizens, who can enroll in training programs within a national aggregator. To help equip citizens for the future world of work, governments could funnel funds toward programs that include the DELTAs associated with employment. For example, trainees could be offered spending vouchers for particular programs only, while funding to program providers could be conditional upon employment outcomes or the provision of training modules that include certain DELTAs.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Ensure affordability of lifelong education</h3>
<p>Most children around the world have access to primary and secondary schooling, but not all of it is of high quality, and early education for the very young—the best age at which to develop certain mindsets and attitudes—is unaffordable for most people in most countries. In addition, very few countries have worked out a system to provide affordable access to quality adult training.</p>
<p>Hence, just as the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century drove an expansion of access to education, today’s technological revolution should drive further expansion to ensure universal, high-quality, affordable access to education from early childhood to retirement and to ensure that curricula include the DELTAs that will future-proof citizens’ skills in the world of work.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid We are less clear, however, about the specific skills tomorrow\u0026rsquo;s workers will require.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eResearch by the McKinsey Global Institute has looked at the kind of jobs that will be lost, as well as those that will be created, as automation, AI, and robotics take hold. And it has inferred the type of high-level skills that will become increasingly important as a result.[[Footnote 1]] The need for manual and physical skills, as well as basic cognitive ones, will decline, but demand for technological, social and emotional, and higher cognitive skills will grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments are keen to help their citizens develop in these areas, but it is hard to devise curricula and the best learning strategies without being more precise about the skills needed. It is difficult to teach what is not well defined.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe, therefore, conducted research that we hope will help definitions take shape and could contribute to future-proof citizens\u0026rsquo; skills for the world of work.[[Footnote 2]] The research identified a set of 56 foundational skills that will benefit all citizens and showed that higher proficiency in them is already associated with a higher likelihood of employment, higher incomes, and job satisfaction.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDefining foundational skills for citizens\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome work will, of course, be specialized. But in a labor market that is more automated, digital, and dynamic, all citizens will benefit from having a set of foundational skills that help them fulfill the following three criteria, no matter the sector in which they work or their occupation:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eadd value beyond what can be done by automated systems and intelligent machines\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eoperate in a digital environment\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003econtinually adapt to new ways of working and new occupations\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe used academic research and McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s experience in adult training to define what these foundational skills might be (Exhibit 1). We started from four broad skill categories\u0026mdash;cognitive, digital, interpersonal, and self-leadership\u0026mdash;then identified 13 separate skill groups belonging to those categories.[[Footnote 4]] Communication and mental flexibility are two skill groups that belong to the cognitive category, for example, while teamwork effectiveness belongs to the interpersonal category.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eLooking for still more precision, we identified 56 distinct elements of talent (DELTAs) that fall within these skills groups. We call them DELTAs, rather than skills, because they are a mix of skills and attitudes. \u0026ldquo;Adaptability\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;coping with uncertainty\u0026rdquo; are attitudes, for example.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDELTA proficiency and outcomes\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom here, we conducted two further pieces of research. First, we sought to gauge the level of proficiency in the 56 DELTAs among today\u0026rsquo;s workers compared with the level we believe will be required to future-proof citizens\u0026rsquo; ability to work. Second, we sought to gauge whether proficiency in these DELTAs was already associated with certain work-related outcomes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eProficiency\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo ascertain proficiency levels, we defined a desirable level of proficiency in each of the 56 DELTAs, then devised a psychometric questionnaire to assess respondents\u0026rsquo; proficiency against this bar. Eighteen thousand people from 15 countries completed the online questionnaire and were given a score on a scale of 0 to 100 for each DELTA (see the sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: Evaluating proficiency levels for DELTAs\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe results showed respondents\u0026rsquo; proficiency was lowest in two skill groups in the digital category\u0026mdash;software use and development and understanding digital systems. Proficiency in the skill groups for communication and planning and ways of working\u0026mdash;both in the cognitive category\u0026mdash;was also lower than average (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe also examined whether proficiency was linked to education. Overall, survey participants with a university degree had higher average DELTA proficiency scores than those without, suggesting\u0026mdash;perhaps not surprisingly\u0026mdash;that participants with higher levels of education are better prepared for changes in the workplace. However, a higher level of education is not associated with higher proficiency in all DELTAs. The association holds true for many DELTAs in the cognitive and digital categories. But for many within the self-leadership and interpersonal categories, such as \u0026ldquo;self-confidence,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;coping with uncertainty,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;courage and risk-taking,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;empathy,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;coaching,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;resolving conflicts,\u0026rdquo; there is no such association.[[Footnote 6]] For some DELTAs, more education was associated with lower proficiency, \u0026ldquo;humility\u0026rdquo; being an example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExhibit 3 lists the DELTAs where proficiency has the highest and lowest correlation with the level of education. (Some have a negative coefficient.)\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eOutcomes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe went on to test whether proficiency in the DELTAs was already helping people in the world of work; the results showed that survey respondents with higher DELTA proficiencies were, on average, more likely to be those that were employed, with higher incomes, and higher job satisfaction. Different DELTAs were more strongly associated with these three work-related outcomes, however.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHolding all variables constant\u0026mdash;including demographic variables and proficiency in all other elements\u0026mdash;we found employment was most strongly associated with proficiency in several DELTAs within the self-leadership category, namely \u0026ldquo;adaptability,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;coping with uncertainty,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;synthesizing messages,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;achievement orientation\u0026rdquo; (Exhibit 4, part 1).[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHigh incomes were most strongly associated with proficiency in the four skill groups where overall proficiency levels were lowest among respondents\u0026mdash;namely understanding digital systems, software use and development, planning and ways of working, and communication (the first two fall within the digital category and the latter two within the cognitive category).[[Footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDigital proficiency seems to be particularly associated with higher incomes: a respondent with higher digital proficiency across all digital DELTAs was 41 percent more likely to earn a top-quintile income than respondents with lower digital proficiency.[[Footnote 9]] The equivalent comparison was 30 percent for cognitive DELTAs, 24 percent for self-leadership DELTAs, and 14 percent for interpersonal DELTAs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, the four DELTAs most strongly associated with high incomes were  \u0026ldquo;work-plan development\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;asking the right questions,\u0026rdquo; both in the cognitive category; \u0026ldquo;self-confidence,\u0026rdquo; a self-leadership DELTA; and \u0026ldquo;organizational awareness,\u0026rdquo; an interpersonal DELTA (Exhibit 4, part 2).[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[CEROS 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eJob satisfaction is also associated with certain DELTAs, especially those in the self-leadership category. Holding all variables, including income, constant, \u0026ldquo;self-motivation and wellness,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;coping with uncertainty,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;self-confidence,\u0026rdquo; had the highest impact on respondents\u0026rsquo; job satisfaction (Exhibit 4, part 3).[[Footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotably, proficiency in two self-leadership DELTAs\u0026mdash;\u0026ldquo;self-confidence\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;coping with uncertainty\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;ranked among the top three most predictive DELTAs for two out of the three outcomes (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow DELTAs could help shape education and adult training\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur findings help define the particular skills citizens are likely to require in the future world of work and suggest how proficiency in them can influence work-related outcomes, namely employment, income, and job satisfaction. This, in turn, suggests three actions governments may wish to take.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReform education systems\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research suggests governments could consider reviewing and updating curricula to focus more strongly on the DELTAs. Given the weak correlation between proficiency in self-leadership and interpersonal DELTAs and higher levels of education, a strong curricula focus on these soft skills may be appropriate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments could also consider leading further research. Many governments and academics have started to define the taxonomies of the skills citizens will require, but few have done so at the level described here. Moreover, few, if any, have undertaken the considerable amount of research required to identify how best to develop and assess such skills. For instance, for each DELTA within the curriculum, research would be required to define progression and proficiency levels achievable at different ages and to design and test developmental strategies and assessment models. The solutions for different DELTAs are likely to differ widely. For example, the solutions to develop and assess \u0026ldquo;self-awareness and self-management\u0026rdquo; would differ from those required for \u0026ldquo;work-plan development or \u0026ldquo;data analysis.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, governments could consider setting up institutions for research and innovation in education to fund the research, facilitate researchers\u0026rsquo; access to schools to test innovative solutions, and establish which methods work for which DELTAs. They could also make the emerging data and insights available to researchers and educators in the private sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReform adult-training systems\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe majority of respondents we surveyed\u0026mdash;like the majority of people in society at large\u0026mdash;were no longer in national education systems. Raising proficiency in the DELTAs would therefore require continuous adult training. The fact that proficiency in digital DELTAs\u0026mdash;shown to improve the chances of achieving higher incomes\u0026mdash;was lower among older survey respondents who had left the national educational system illustrates this point.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe curricula of adult-training courses may also have to change. For example, our research has shown that self-leadership DELTAs may be particularly important for employment outcomes, yet these are not commonly covered by adult-training programs. For example, in an online scan of adult-training programs, we found that courses or modules to develop DELTAs within the skill groups of goal achievement or self-awareness and self-management were 20 times less common than those to develop communication DELTAs. That could be an urgent gap to fill to adequately respond to the wave of unemployment caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpecific actions that might encourage relevant adult learning include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEstablish an AI aggregator of training programs to attract adult learners and encourage lifelong learning. \u003c/em\u003eAI algorithms could guide users on whether they need to upskill or reskill for a new profession and shortlist relevant training programs. To develop accurate algorithms, governments would need to collect and organize data on market demand for jobs and skills, as well as data on training programs. Programs listed should include those that teach DELTAs correlated to work-related outcomes. Self-leadership DELTAs could be particularly important given their link to employment.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntroduce a skill-based certification system.\u003c/em\u003e Occupation-based qualifications risk becoming outdated rapidly as occupations requiring new skills emerge. Hence, skills-based accreditation may better suit employers\u0026rsquo; needs. Providers could develop programs that cover the practical skills and DELTAs required to perform a certain occupation, but add new components or remove old ones as those occupations evolved. Several AI start-ups have developed algorithms capable of identifying and updating the skill sets required for different occupations. Governments could adapt these to enable a dynamic, skill-based certification system.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFund schemes that encourage a higher focus on DELTAs.\u003c/em\u003e Some governments award lifelong learning grants to their citizens, who can enroll in training programs within a national aggregator. To help equip citizens for the future world of work, governments could funnel funds toward programs that include the DELTAs associated with employment. For example, trainees could be offered spending vouchers for particular programs only, while funding to program providers could be conditional upon employment outcomes or the provision of training modules that include certain DELTAs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnsure affordability of lifelong education\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost children around the world have access to primary and secondary schooling, but not all of it is of high quality, and early education for the very young\u0026mdash;the best age at which to develop certain mindsets and attitudes\u0026mdash;is unaffordable for most people in most countries. In addition, very few countries have worked out a system to provide affordable access to quality adult training.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence, just as the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century drove an expansion of access to education, today\u0026rsquo;s technological revolution should drive further expansion to ensure universal, high-quality, affordable access to education from early childhood to retirement and to ensure that curricula include the DELTAs that will future-proof citizens\u0026rsquo; skills in the world of work.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-06-25T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor more information, see \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/skill-shift-automation-and-the-future-of-the-workforce\"\u003eSkill shift: Automation and the future of the workforce\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; May 23, 2018.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor previous McKinsey work on the role of governments in adapting to the future of work, see Marco Dondi, Solveigh Hieronimus, Julia Klier, Peter Puskas, Dirk Schmautzer, and J\u0026ouml;rg Schubert, \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/a-government-blueprint-to-adapt-the-ecosystem-to-the-future-of-work\"\u003eA government blueprint to adapt the ecosystem to the future of work\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;February 7, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe research was conducted in 2019.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTo drive toward a more detailed definition of future skills required, we found it useful to divide the social and emotional category used by the McKinsey Global Institute into two separate ones: interpersonal and self-leadership.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA still finer segmentation of each skill group into more DELTAs would be possible. We limited ourselves, however, to DELTAs that require a distinct approach to their development and assessment.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePredictive models based on three different statistical techniques failed to find a correlation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThese DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution\u0026mdash;holding all other variables constant\u0026mdash;to the probability of a survey participant being employed among those whose income was below the median or those with no income. People with income above the median were excluded to avoid skewed results because of their higher proficiency in DELTAs. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThese skill groups show the largest difference in proficiency between survey participants with income below the median income in their country and those in the top quintile.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOur assessment model had three levels of proficiency (3 being the highest level) for each of the 56 DELTAs. Here, respondents with higher digital proficiency are those judged to be at level 3. Those with lower digital proficiency are those at level 2. All else being constant, a respondent at level 3 is 41% more likely to be earning a top-quintile income than a respondent at level 2.  \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThese DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution\u0026mdash;holding all other variables constant\u0026mdash;to the probability of a survey participant being in the top quintile for income.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThese DELTAs were selected based on their individual contribution\u0026mdash;holding all other variables constant\u0026mdash;to the probability of a survey participant being either
